publicationStmt.p: This is an XML-TEI markup of the original publications by SIL Mexico for the purposes of: archival and for the creation of a body of Mixtepec-Mixtec language resources (LR) (ISO: mix). Encoded documents used with the permission of original authors.

notesStmt.note: En el pueblo de Mixtepec había un sabino muy alto. Era tan alto que la punta tocaba las nubes, pero un día los ancianos del pueblo acordaron cortar el árbol.

sourceDesc.bibl:
Francisco Mendoza Santiago Gisela Beckmann María M. Nieves Instituto Lingüístico de Verano, A.C. Tlalpan, D.F., México
second 2009 Obtained from:

textDesc.channel: @mode:'w' means that the primary means of utilising this document is by reading it's written form;
textDesc.derivation: this document is labeled "original" because the XML-TEI markup of it's contents have not made any alterations to the original content;

normalization.ab: 2018-02-19Spelling of lexical items which in the old orthography were homographs and which have been changed according to updated orthographic principles as per ../Mille/GUIA_ORTOGRAFICA_PRELIMINAR_Short_version.xml. Instances of "ña" still remain to be changed pending consultation with Mille (or other person working on orthography). In this document the extended senses of "face" - "nuu" were not normalized as I am awaiting discussion as to whether this particular sense should also be changed to "nu".

list.item: Mixtec content found at following locations: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg/w

English translations are defined in relation to their Mixtec equivalents in the following location: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/spanGrp[@type='translation']/span the value of //span[@target] is the pointer to the Mixtec translation equivalentwhere preceding sibling is: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg

Spanish translations are defined in relation to their Mixtec equivalents in the following location: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/spanGrp[@type='translation']/span the value of //span[@target] is the pointer to the Mixtec translation equivalentwhere preceding sibling is: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg

spanGrp.span: This is a story about our town, a sabine tree stood, a big sabine tree, the biggest of all trees.
Este es un cuento sobre nuestro pueblo, había un sabino, un sabino grande, el mejor de todos los árboles.
the biggest of all the trees
el mejor de todos los árboles
And one day a great big eagle came to live there, the eagle came to live, it wanted to sit down on top.
Y un día un agila vinó a vivir allí, la agila vinó a vivir, quería sentarse por encima.
The people did not allow it to land, they began to shoot at it, they scared it, they chased it off and it flew away and left.
La gente no le permitieron aterrizar, empezaron tirarle, le asustaron, lo perseguiron, y salió volando y se fue.
And at the bottom half there was a laguna where water was gathered, where water the people and the animals would (?come to? drink from?)
And the people said that they should cut it and so they chopped it down.
Y la gente dijeron que lo deberían cortarlo, entonces lo cortaron.
Then they began, they choped the Sabine tree, many people gathered, they wanted it to fall.
Y empezaron, cortaron el sabino, mucha gente reunieron, querían que lo caya.
And when the next day came, (?), they went back to chopping.
Y cuando llegó el día sigente,(?), continuaron a cortar.
this is for sure completive! now make note when you see it without "ni" elsewhere.
And then the people realized that they wouldn't be able to chop the tree down.
Y entonces la gente se daron cuento de que ello no irían reusir a cortar el árbol.
The people gathered, the people came to help their kinsmen in chopping the tree (in half/down?); (??) they were able to help chop down the tree, the Sabine tree.
is this "na" meaning 'they/the people'? If not what is it? and if yes, what is it doing after "ka"?
this is an actual example of an uniflected verb. Check on whether it is actually the lemma!
"vatu ni" is this together? Get other uses of this and certain other forms.
And then the Sabine fell, .....fell of in two two parts.
Half of it fell in (placeName?), half fell in (placeName?)
If this is "yuku" as in forest, it should be spelled "yukú"
That is where the story of the the great big sabine tree of San Juan Mixtepec ends.
Aquel es dónde termine el cuento del sabino grande de San Juan Mixtepec.
is this the "end" of the story or the "end/destruction" of the tree?
The people say, they inhabited a long time ago, they know the story about the tree that used to be in this town.
La gente dicen, ellos habitaron hace mucho tiempo, saben el cuento del árbol que estuvo en este pueblo.
